item.title: Bertrand Price Competition
item.description: Firms will choose price as the strategic variable. Market Demand x(p)=A−bp where A,b are constants Simultaneous game Firm with lower price captures all of demand Case: Constant and Same Marginal Cost § Marginal Cost is constant for both firms: c(x)=cx, MC=c Both firms will attempt to undercut each other.

item.title: Besset Correction
item.description: Review and intuition why we divide by n-1 for the unbiased sample | Khan Academy - YouTube Naiive sample variance estimator: s^2=n∑i=1n​(xi​−xˉ)​ ⇒ Sample variance is biased.

item.title: Beveridge Curve
item.description: Beveridge Curve § := description of the inverse correlation between Unemployment and job openings It may shift due to: increased in unemployment benefits, participation rate changes, etc.

item.title: Bias (Statistics)
item.description: Note Bias is the difference between the expected value [=mean] of an estimator and the ground truth. Bias[θ^]=E[θ^]−θ0​ thm. Linear Transformation Preserves Bias.

item.title: Big-Oh Notation
item.description: Alternative formulation of parts of calculus. def. Big-Oh Notation. for functions f,g, we say f(n)=O(g(n)) iff: Definition 1: ∃c∈R+ ∀n∈N+,f(n)≤c⋅g(n) Definition 2: n→∞lim​sup(f(n))<∞ ⇒ Intuitive Understanding: f=O(g)≈f<g def.

item.title: Binomial Distribution
item.description: Binomial Distribution § def. Binomial Distribution. For random variable X which denotes the number of successes within n trials with success probability p: XP(X=k)​∼Binom(n,p)=(kn​)⋅pk⋅(1−p)n−k​ E[X]=np Var[X]=n⋅p(1−p) .

item.title: Binomial Option Pricing Model
item.description: Binomial Option Pricing Model § Q. What is the fair price (=No-Arbitrage) of a European call option at time t0​? You can’t really just use Present Value Calculations because it’s a derivative.

item.title: Binomial Security Pricing Model
item.description: Model Definition § Consider time interval [t0​,tf​] total time τ=tf​−t0​ n intervals hn​: duration of one interval (=ntf​−t0​​) St​: price of security at time t.

item.title: Bivariate Ordinary Least Squares Regression
item.description: Motivation. Let’s say that there is a relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. Maybe god has declared a perfect formula describing this relationship: GDP Per Capita=200⋅Life Expectancy+1000+Noise While we humans may never truly know the parameters of the formula, 200 and 1000, we can still make a good guess about it.
